title: Parallel Clique Counting and Peeling Algorithms

sections.introduction:
Finding k𝑘k-cliques in a graph is a fundamental
graph-theoretic problem with a long history of study both in theory
and practice. In recent years, k𝑘k-clique counting and listing have
been widely applied in practice due to their many applications,
including in learning network embeddings ,
understanding the structure and formation of
networks  , identifying dense subgraphs for
community detection  8  , and
graph partitioning and compression . For sparse graphs, the best known sequential algorithm is by Chiba and
Nishizeki , and requires O​(m​αk−2)𝑂𝑚superscript𝛼𝑘2O(m\alpha^{k-2}) work
(number of operations), where α𝛼\alpha is the arboricity of the
graph.111A graph has arboricity α𝛼\alpha if the minimum number of spanning forests needed to cover the graph is α𝛼\alpha. The state-of-the-art clique parallel k𝑘k-clique counting algorithm is
kClist , which achieves the same work bound,
but does not have a strong theoretical bound on the
span (parallel time). Furthermore, kClist as well as existing parallel k𝑘k-clique counting
algorithms have limited scalability for graphs with more than a few
hundred million edges, but real-world graphs today frequently contain
billions to hundreds of billions of edges [ref]34. k𝑘k-clique Counting.
In this paper, we design a new parallel k𝑘k-clique counting algorithm,
arb-count that matches the work of Chiba-Nishezeki, has
polylogarithmic span, and has improved space complexity compared to
kClist. Our algorithm is able to significantly outperform kClist and
other competitors, and scale to larger graphs than prior work.
arb-count is based on using low out-degree orientations of the graph
to reduce the total work.
Assuming that we have a low out-degree ranking of the graph, we show
that for a constant k𝑘k we can count or list all k𝑘k-cliques in
O​(m​αk−2)𝑂𝑚superscript𝛼𝑘2O(m\alpha^{k-2}) work, and O​(k​log⁡n+log2⁡n)𝑂𝑘𝑛superscript2𝑛O(k\log n+\log^{2}n) span with high probability (whp),222We say O​(f​(n))𝑂𝑓𝑛O(f(n)) with
high probability (whp) to indicate O​(c​f​(n))𝑂𝑐𝑓𝑛O(cf(n)) with probability
at least 1−n−c1superscript𝑛𝑐1-n^{-c} for c≥1𝑐1c\geq 1, where n𝑛n is the input size.
where m𝑚m is the number of edges in the graph and α𝛼\alpha is the
arboricity of the graph. Having work bounds parameterized by α𝛼\alpha is
desirable since most real-world graphs have low
arboricity [ref]17. Theoretically, arb-count requires
O​(α)𝑂𝛼O(\alpha) extra space per processor; in contrast, the kClist algorithm requires O​(α2)𝑂superscript𝛼2O(\alpha^{2}) extra space per processor. Furthermore, kClist does not achieve polylogarithmic span. We also design an approximate k𝑘k-clique counting algorithm
based on counting on a sparsified graph. We show in the appendix that our approximate algorithm
produces unbiased estimates and runs in O​(p​m​αk−2+m)𝑂𝑝𝑚superscript𝛼𝑘2𝑚O(pm\alpha^{k-2}+m)
work and O​(k​log⁡n+log2⁡n)𝑂𝑘𝑛superscript2𝑛O(k\log n+\log^{2}n) span whp for a sampling
probability of p𝑝p. Parallel Ranking Algorithms.
We present two new parallel algorithms
for efficiently ranking the vertices, which we use for k𝑘k-clique counting. We show that a distributed
algorithm by Barenboim and Elkin  can be implemented
in linear work and polylogarithmic span. We also parallelize an
external-memory algorithm by Goodrich and Pszona  and
obtain the same complexity bounds.
We believe that our parallel ranking algorithms may be of
independent interest, as many other subgraph finding algorithms use
low out-degree orderings
(e.g.,   ). Peeling and k𝑘k-Clique Densest Subgraph.
We also present new parallel algorithms for the
k𝑘k-clique densest subgraph problem, a generalization of the densest subgraph problem
that was first introduced by Tsourakakis . This
problem admits a natural 1/k1𝑘1/k-approximation by peeling vertices in
order of their incident k𝑘k-clique counts. We present a parallel peeling
algorithm, arb-peel, that peels all vertices with the
lowest k𝑘k-clique count on each round and uses arb-count as a subroutine.
The expected amortized work of arb-peel is O​(m​αk−2+ρk​(G)​log⁡n)𝑂𝑚superscript𝛼𝑘2subscript𝜌𝑘𝐺𝑛O(m\alpha^{k-2}+\rho_{k}(G)\log n) and
the span is O​(ρk​(G)​k​log⁡n+log2⁡n)𝑂subscript𝜌𝑘𝐺𝑘𝑛superscript2𝑛O(\rho_{k}(G)k\log n+\log^{2}n) whp, where ρk​(G)subscript𝜌𝑘𝐺\rho_{k}(G) is the
number of rounds needed to completely peel the graph.
We also prove in the appendix that the problem of obtaining the hierarchy given by
this process is 𝖯𝖯\mathsf{P}-complete for k>2𝑘2k>2, indicating that a polylogarithmic-span
solution is unlikely. Tsourakakis also shows that naturally extending the Bahmani et
al.  algorithm for approximate densest subgraph gives
an 1/(k​(1+ϵ))1𝑘1italic-ϵ1/(k(1+\epsilon))-approximation in O​(log⁡n)𝑂𝑛O(\log n) parallel
rounds, although they were not concerned about work.
We present
an O​(m​αk−2)𝑂𝑚superscript𝛼𝑘2O(m\alpha^{k-2}) work and polylogarithmic-span algorithm,
arb-approx-peel, for obtaining a 1/(k​(1+ϵ))1𝑘1italic-ϵ1/(k(1+\epsilon))-approximation to
the k𝑘k-clique densest subgraph problem. We obtain this work bound using our k𝑘k-clique algorithm as a subroutine.
Danisch et al.  use their k𝑘k-clique counting
algorithm as a subroutine to implement these two approximation
algorithms for k𝑘k-clique densest subgraph, but their implementations do not have
provably-efficient bounds. Experimental Evaluation.
We present implementations of our algorithms that use various
optimizations to achieve good practical performance. We
perform a thorough experimental study on a 30-core
machine with two-way hyper-threading and compare to prior work.
We show that on a variety of real-world graphs and different
k𝑘k, our k𝑘k-clique counting algorithm achieves 1.31–9.88x speedup over the
state-of-the-art parallel kClist algorithm  and
self-relative speedups of 13.23–38.99x.
We also compared our k𝑘k-clique counting algorithm to other
parallel k𝑘k-clique counting implementations including Jain and Seshadhri’s
Pivoter , Mhedhbi and Salihoglu’s worst-case optimal
join algorithm (WCO) , Lai et al.’s
implementation of a binary join algorithm (BinaryJoin)
, and Pinar et al.’s ESCAPE
, and demonstrate speedups of up to several orders of
magnitude. Furthermore, by integrating state-of-the-art parallel graph
compression techniques, we can process graphs
with tens to hundreds of billions of edges, significantly
improving on the capabilities of existing implementations. As
far as we know, we are the first to report 444-clique counts for
Hyperlink2012, the largest publicly-available graph, with over
two hundred billion undirected edges. We study the accuracy-time tradeoff of our sampling algorithm, and
show that is able to approximate the clique counts with 5.05% error
5.32–6573.63 times more quickly than running our exact counting
algorithm on the same graph. We compare our sampling algorithm to
Bressan et al.’s serial MOTIVO ,
and demonstrate 92.71–177.29x speedups. Finally, we study our two
parallel approximation algorithms for k𝑘k-clique densest subgraph and show that our we are
able to outperform kClist by up to 29.59x and achieve 1.19–13.76x
self-relative speedup. We demonstrate up to 53.53x speedup over Fang
et al.’s serial CoreApp  as well. The contributions of this paper are as follows: A parallel algorithm with O​(m​αk−2)𝑂𝑚superscript𝛼𝑘2O(m\alpha^{k-2}) and polylogarithmic
span whp for k𝑘k-clique counting. Parallel algorithms for low out-degree
orientations with O​(m)𝑂𝑚O(m) work and O​(log2⁡n)𝑂superscript2𝑛O(\log^{2}n) span whp. An O​(m​αk−2)𝑂𝑚superscript𝛼𝑘2O(m\alpha^{k-2}) amortized expected work parallel algorithm for
computing a 1/k1𝑘1/k-approximation to the k𝑘k-clique densest subgraph problem, and an O​(m​αk−2)𝑂𝑚superscript𝛼𝑘2O(m\alpha^{k-2}) work and polylogarithmic-span whp
algorithm for computing a 1/(k​(1+ϵ))1𝑘1italic-ϵ1/(k(1+\epsilon))-approximation. Optimized implementations of our algorithms that achieve
significant speedups over existing state-of-the-art methods, and
scale to the largest publicly-available graphs. Our code is publicly available at: https://github.com/ParAlg/gbbs/tree/master/benchmarks/CliqueCounting.
